name: Tony
comment info:
I notice that for the ten most vaccinated states, the increase, and average in general, was a lot lower than for the ten least vaccinated states. For adults in the ten most vaccinated states, things were going pretty well until the delta variant was discovered. For adults in the other graph, things were going even better, starting out at about a 2.7 ish, and decreasing to a 1.5 ish. But after the variant was discovered, things took quite a dramatic turn. The more vaccinated adults shot up, back to 3 admissions, but that increase paled in comparison with the increase in the less vaccinated states- going from 1.5 ish, to 9.5 ish. For teens in the vaccinated states, life was pretty dull, remaining at about 0.5 ish the entire time. Teens in the less vaccinated states fared less well, staying at a constant three quarters before the variant was discovered and it shot up to 2 and a half. 
Headline: The Covid Rollercoaster

It shows that in the most vaccinated states, there are WAY fewer hospitalizations in children and adults than in the least vaccinated states, which have been rising due to the recent Delta variant outbreak. It is living proof that the vaccines have been working keeping hospitalizations at bay. In the least vaccinated states, it is also showing people under 18 being in the hospital with a large wave in the graph while the vaccinated states are at a steady pace with the number of children in the hospital. As younger people get vaccinated and get approved for younger children under 12 it hopefully will even go down even further. It also recently has greatly increased in children due to the amount going back to in-person school where COVID-19 can be easily spread. Recently things have been picking up again, so please get vaccinated and wear a mask if you are able to protect yourself and everyone else!

comment info:
Difference of Data for Covid Hospitalizations
From the evidence provided in the article, it can be seen that while the 10 most and least vaccinated states start off May with a lowering rate of hospitalizations for adults and minors; there's a greater increase of those who need hospitalization in least vaccinated states. Although both sides have an increase of hospitalizations recently, it can be seen that the states with the least amount of vaccinations are having more cases of Covid-19. I wonder if the areas of the states which do/do not have the most vaccinations has anything to do with the rising or decreasing cases of the virus needing hospitalization. I'm also curious about if the hospitalizations recorded are more confirmed or suspected Covid-19 cases since it's stated that there's both on the graph. Relating to my community, this graph represents a neighboring state of mine which can be an accurate representation of how my state may be doing. replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Aaden Lundeen 

Hello Aaden,

While the data for these graphs is gathered from the 10 states with the highest vaccination rates and the 10 with the lowest, these graphs do not show those vaccination rates.  Instead, the graphs are helping to compare hospitalization rates between those two sets of states for two groups of people—adults and people under the age of 18. 

When data is collected as a rate, this allows states with large populations to be compared to those with small populations.  

For example, Arizona and Kansas have about 50% fully vaccinated (seehttps://www.mayoclinic.org/coronavirus-covid-19/vaccine-tracker)  but Arizona’s population is more than double that of Kansas.  This keeps us from using state population data in the “wrong way” as you asked in your question.

replies.comment info:
HI, @George --

No, George, this graph does not tell you where Pennsylvania is on the scale of vaccination rates.  
Think why the New York Times picked the top and bottom ten states for the two graphs. What do these two graph show?

Regarding why 100,000 people, very frequently state Covid statistics use statistics with rates rather number since states have such different population sizes.  For example, a large number may be because there is a lot of Covid or it may be because the state has a large population.  If rates (for example, 100,000)are used, states of different sizes can be compared.  Rates are also used for population groups, such as here with the larger adults group and the smaller less than 18 year olds.

Though the graph may not give you enough information on whether you should get a vaccine shot, it does show the association between vaccine rates and hospitalizations for two population groups:  adults and under 18 year olds.  Based on the information in the graphs, where would you rather live (I’m assuming that you are under 18 years old)  -- in one of the most or least vaccinated states?

name: Ashlyn
comment info:
1. I notice that the ten least vaccinated states have higher hospital admissions. This makes sense because without being vaccinated, your body cannot fight it off as well as it would be able to if you were vaccinated. I also noticed that the percentage of adults who are not vaccinated and in the hospital is greater than the percentage of people aged 18 and under. 
2. I wonder why the percentage of adults in the hospital is greater than the percentage of people aged 18 and under. What role does age play in getting COVID? Is the amount of adults getting vaccinated less than the amount of people aged 18 and under getting vaccinated? What plays a role in the most vs. least vaccinated states?

Hence, since less people are getting hospitalized, this means that our community can get to a new normal faster than the states with the least amount of people vaccinated.

name: Loke Zhang-Fiskesjo
comment info:
Doctors hate this one easy trick to instantly reduce outbreaks.

---

I notice ... 

Both growths rose but the ten least vaccinated states had skyrocketing cases going up to 8-9 new daily hospitalizations per person compared to the lesser 3 new daily hospitalizations per adults. For minors in the most vaccinated cases, their severe case numbers continued to nearly stagnate like it were before Delta was identified in the U.S. This is while minors' severe cases rose severely relative to previous case counts in the 10 least vaccinated states.

I wonder... 

Who makes up the majority of adult cases?

Who makes up the majority of the minors cases?

Who does the vaccine protect?

---

The graphs reveal when that age group under 18 has far less severe cases as well as adults. This could entail that children in more vaccinated are more able to attend school in-person as well as adults being able to interact in-person. The number of severe cases that could've been instigated by the exponential spread in unvaccinated states might influence covid to be harder to contain and potentially mutate in various ways. Ultimately, vaccinated states are less overwhelmed and are more likely to sustain more normal and functional living not disrupted by various outbreaks.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Aaden Lundeen 

Hello Aaden,

While the data for these graphs is gathered from the 10 states with the highest vaccination rates and the 10 with the lowest, these graphs do not show those vaccination rates.  Instead, the graphs are helping to compare hospitalization rates between those two sets of states for two groups of people—adults and people under the age of 18. 

When data is collected as a rate, this allows states with large populations to be compared to those with small populations.  

For example, Arizona and Kansas have about 50% fully vaccinated (seehttps://www.mayoclinic.org/coronavirus-covid-19/vaccine-tracker)  but Arizona’s population is more than double that of Kansas.  This keeps us from using state population data in the “wrong way” as you asked in your question.

As my co-moderator Sharon replied previously, an online search for “What is suspected Covid?” leads to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) memo on how cases are classified.  

(https://ndc.services.cdc.gov/case-definitions/coronavirus-disease-2019-2021/).

After reading the explanation at this link, you decide if numbers are “added in to make people think the vaccine works.”

replies.comment info:
HI, @George --

No, George, this graph does not tell you where Pennsylvania is on the scale of vaccination rates.  
Think why the New York Times picked the top and bottom ten states for the two graphs. What do these two graph show?

Regarding why 100,000 people, very frequently state Covid statistics use statistics with rates rather number since states have such different population sizes.  For example, a large number may be because there is a lot of Covid or it may be because the state has a large population.  If rates (for example, 100,000)are used, states of different sizes can be compared.  Rates are also used for population groups, such as here with the larger adults group and the smaller less than 18 year olds.

Though the graph may not give you enough information on whether you should get a vaccine shot, it does show the association between vaccine rates and hospitalizations for two population groups:  adults and under 18 year olds.  Based on the information in the graphs, where would you rather live (I’m assuming that you are under 18 years old)  -- in one of the most or least vaccinated states?
